standard_metadata.standard_description: Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Decimals in written and expanded form

question.content: **Which two of the following expressions have the same value as $8.76$?**

hints.content: Let's use a place value table to write each expression in standard form.

### Expression: $\purpleC{\text{Eight}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{\text{sixty-seven hundredths}}$   The $\blueD{\text{and}}$ tells us where to put the decimal.  We write $\text{\purpleC{eight}}$ to the left side of the decimal as $\purpleC8$.  We write $\text{\greenD{sixty-seven hundredths}}$ to the right side of the decimal as $\greenD{67}$ .   The last place value in the number is *hundredths*, so the number ends in the *hundredths* place.  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC8$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD6$ | $\greenD7$  $8.67 \neq 8.76$

###Expression: $\purpleC{8 \text{ ones}}+\greenD{7 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{6 \text{ hundredths}}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC8$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD7$ | $\goldD6$  $8.76 = 8.76$

###Expression: $\purpleC{(8\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 7\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$  $\begin{align} \purpleC{(8\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 7\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \purpleC{8}+\greenD{0.7}+\goldD{ 0.06}  \end{align}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC8$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD7$ | $\goldD6$  $8.76 = 8.76$

###Expression:  $\purpleC8+\greenD{0.7}+\maroonD{0.006}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC8$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD7$ | $0$| $\maroonD6$  $8.706 \neq 8.76$

The following expressions have the same value as $8.76$:  * $\purpleC{8 \text{ ones}}+\greenD{7 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{6 \text{ hundredths}}$  * $\purpleC{(8\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 7\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$

question.content: **Which two of the following have the same value as $1.303$?**

options.content: One and three hundred three thousandths

hints.content: Let's use a place value table to write each expression in standard form.

### Expression: $\purpleC{\text{One}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{\text{three hundred-}}$$\maroonD{\text{three thousandths}}$   The $\blueD{\text{and}}$ tells us where to put the decimal.  We write $\text{\purpleC{one}}$ to the left side of the decimal as $\purpleC1$.  We write $\greenD{\text{three hundred-}}$$\maroonD{\text{three thousandths}}$ to the right side of the decimal as $\greenD{3}0\maroonD3$ .   The last place value in the number is *thousandths*, so the number ends in the *thousandths* place.  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC1$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$| $0$ | $\maroonD3$  $1.303 = 1.303$

###Expression: $\purpleC{3 \text{ ones}}+\greenD{3 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{3 \text{ thousandths}}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC3$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$ | $0$| $\goldD3$  $3.303 \neq 1.303$

###Expression: $\purpleC{(1\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (3\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$  $\begin{align} \purpleC{(1\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (3\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \purpleC{1}+\greenD{0.3}+\goldD{ 0.03}  \end{align}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC1$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$ | $\goldD3$  $1.33 \neq 1.303$

###Expression:  $\purpleC1+\greenD{0.3}+\maroonD{0.003}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC1$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$ | $0$ |$\maroonD3$  $1.303 = 1.303$

The following expressions have the same value as $1.303$:  * $\purpleC1+\greenD{0.3}+\maroonD{0.003}$  * $\purpleC{\text{One}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{\text{three hundred-}}$$\maroonD{\text{three thousandths}}$

question.content: **Which two of the following have the same value as $18$ ones and $302$ thousandths?**

hints.content: ### Expression: $\purpleC{18\text{ ones}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{302\text{ thousandths}}$   First, let's turn $18$ ones and $302$ thousandths into standard form using a place value chart.  The $\blueD{\text{and}}$ tells us where to put the decimal.  We write $\text{\purpleC{18 ones}}$ to the left side of the decimal as $\purpleC{18}$.  We write $\greenD{302\text{ thousandths}}$ to the right side of the decimal as $\greenD{302}$ .   The last place value in the number is *thousandths*, so the number ends in the *thousandths* place.  Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC1$| $\purpleC8$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$| $\greenD0$ | $\greenD2$  So, we are looking for expressions that are equivalent to $\purpleC{18}\blueD{.}\greenD{302}$.
Now, let's use a place value table to write each expression in standard form.

###Expression:  $\blueD{1}\greenD{8}{,}\maroonD{3}0\purpleC{2}$   Ten Thousands| Thousands| Hundreds| Tens | Ones  :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\blueD{1}$| $\greenD8$| $\maroonD3$| $0$ | $\purpleC{2}$   $18{,}302 \neq 18.302$

###Expression: $\maroonD{1\text{ ten}} + \purpleC{8 \text{ ones}}+\greenD{3 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{2 \text{ thousandths}}$  Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\maroonD1$| $\purpleC8$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$ | $0$| $\goldD2$  $18.302 = 18.302$

###Expression: $\maroonD{{1\times10}} + \purpleC{(8\times1)}+\tealD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )}$  $\begin{align} \maroonD{{1\times10}} + \purpleC{(8\times1)}+\tealD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )} = \maroonD1+\purpleC{8}+\tealD{0.03}+\goldD{ 0.002}  \end{align}$  Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\maroonD1$| $\purpleC8$ |$\blueD.$  | $0$| $\tealD{3}$ | $\goldD2$  $18.032 \neq 18.302$

###Expression: $\maroonD{{1\times10}} + \purpleC{(8\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )}$  $\begin{align} \maroonD{{1\times10}} + \purpleC{(8\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )} = \maroonD1+\purpleC{8}+\greenD{0.3}+\goldD{ 0.002}  \end{align}$  Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\maroonD1$| $\purpleC8$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$| $0$ | $\goldD2$  $18.302 = 18.302$

The following expressions have the same value as $18$ ones and $302$ thousandths:  * $\maroonD{1\text{ ten}} + \purpleC{8 \text{ ones}}+\greenD{3 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{2 \text{ thousandths}}$  * $\maroonD{{1\times10}} + \purpleC{(8\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )}$

question.content: **Which two of the following have the same value as $50.96$?**

hints.content: Let's use a place value table to write each expression in standard form.

### Expression: $\purpleC{\text{Fifty}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{\text{ninety-six thousandths}}$   The $\blueD{\text{and}}$ tells us where to put the decimal.  We write $\text{\purpleC{fifty}}$ to the left side of the decimal as $\purpleC{50}$.  We write $\text{\greenD{ninety-six thousandths}}$ to the right side of the decimal as $\greenD{096}$ .   The last place value in the number is *thousandths*, so the number ends in the *thousandths* place.  Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC5$| $\purpleC0$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD0$| $\greenD9$ | $\greenD6$  $50.096 \neq 50.96$

###Expression: $\purpleC{5 \text{ tens}} +\greenD{9 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{6 \text{ hundredths}}$  Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC5$| $\purpleC0$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD9$ | $\goldD6$  $50.96 = 50.96$

###Expression: $\purpleC{(5\times10)}+\greenD{\left ( 9\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$  $\begin{align} \purpleC{(5\times10)}+\greenD{\left ( 9\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \purpleC{50}+\greenD{0.9}+\goldD{ 0.06}  \end{align}$  Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC5$| $\purpleC0$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD9$ | $\goldD6$  $50.96 = 50.96$
###Expression:  $\purpleC5+\greenD{0.9}+\maroonD{0.06}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC5$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD9$ | $\maroonD6$  $5.96 \neq 50.96$

The following expressions have the same value as $50.96$:  * $\purpleC{5 \text{ tens}} +\greenD{9 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{6 \text{ hundredths}}$  * $\purpleC{(5\times10)}+\greenD{\left ( 9\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$

question.content: **Which two of the following have the same value as $2$ ones and $96$ thousandths?**

hints.content: ### Expression: $\purpleC{2\text{ ones}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{96\text{ thousandths}}$   First, let's turn $2$ ones and $96$ thousandths into standard form using a place value chart.  The $\blueD{\text{and}}$ tells us where to put the decimal.  We write $\text{\purpleC{2 ones}}$ to the left side of the decimal as $\purpleC{2}$.  We write $\greenD{96\text{ thousandths}}$ to the right side of the decimal as $\greenD{096}$ .   The last place value in the number is *thousandths*, so the number ends in the *thousandths* place.   Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC2$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD0$| $\greenD9$ | $\greenD6$  So, we are looking for expressions that are equivalent to $\purpleC{2}\blueD{.}\greenD{096}$.
Now, let's use a place value table to write each expression in standard form.

###Expression:  $\purpleC2.{0}\greenD{9}\goldD6$    Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC2$ |$\blueD.$  | $0$| $\greenD9$ | $\goldD6$  $2.096 = 2.096$

###Expression: $\purpleC{2 \text{ ones}}+\redD{9 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{6 \text{ thousandths}}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $\purpleC2$ |$\blueD.$  | $\redD{9}$ | $0$| $\goldD6$  $2.906 \neq 2.096$

###Expression: $\maroonD{{(2\times10)}} +\greenD{\left ( 9\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}+\goldD{\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )}$  $\begin{align} \maroonD{{(2\times10)}} +\greenD{\left ( 9\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}+\goldD{\left (6\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )} = \maroonD2+\greenD{0.09}+\goldD{ 0.006}  \end{align}$  Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\maroonD2$| $\maroonD0$ |$\blueD.$  | $0$| $\greenD9$ | $\goldD6$  $20.096 \neq 2.096$

###Expression:  $\purpleC2+\greenD{0.09}+\goldD{0.006}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC2$ |$\blueD.$  | $0$ | $\greenD9$| $\goldD{6}$  $2.906 = 2.906$
The following expressions have the same value as $2$ ones and $96$ thousandths:  * $\purpleC2.{0}\greenD{9}\goldD6$  *  $\purpleC2+\greenD{0.09}+\goldD{0.006}$

question.content: **Which two of the following have the same value as $4.032$?**

hints.content: Let's use a place value table to write each expression in standard form.

### Expression: $\purpleC{\text{Four}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\maroonD{\text{thirty-two thousandths}}$   The $\blueD{\text{and}}$ tells us where to put the decimal.  We write $\text{\purpleC{four}}$ to the left side of the decimal as $\purpleC4$.  We write $\text{\maroonD{thirty-two thousandths}}$ to the right side of the decimal as $\maroonD{032}$ .   The last place value in the number is *thousandths*, so the number ends in the *thousandths* place.  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC4$ |$\blueD.$  | $\maroonD{0}$| $\maroonD{3}$ | $\maroonD{2}$  $4.032 = 4.032$

###Expression: $\purpleC{4 \text{ ones}}+\greenD{3 \text{ tenths}}+\goldD{2 \text{ hundredths}}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC4$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$ | $\goldD2$  $4.32 \neq 4.032$

###Expression: $\purpleC{(4\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$  $\begin{align} \purpleC{(4\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 3\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} = \purpleC{4}+\greenD{0.3}+\goldD{ 0.02}  \end{align}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC4$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD3$ | $\goldD2$  $4.32 \neq 4.032$

###Expression:  $\purpleC4+\goldD{0.03}+\maroonD{0.002}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC4$ |$\blueD.$  | $0$ | $\goldD{3}$ | $\maroonD2$  $4.032 = 4.032$
The following expressions have the same value as $4.032$:  * $\purpleC4+\greenD{0.03}+\maroonD{0.002}$  * $\purpleC{\text{Four}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\maroonD{\text{thirty-two thousandths}}$

question.content: **Complete the chart below.**  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:  $(9\times1)+\left ( 4\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )+\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )$|  |

hints.content: Let's use a place value chart to write $\purpleC{(9\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 4\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$ in standard form.  $\begin{align} &\purpleC{(9\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 4\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )} \\\\  &= \purpleC9+\greenD{0.4}+\goldD{ 0.02}  \end{align}$  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $\purpleC9$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD4$ | $\goldD2$

Now, let's break our number into parts to write it in word form: $\purpleC{9}\blueD{.}\greenD4\goldD2$  $\purpleC{\text{Nine}}$ is to the left of the decimal.   The decimal tells us to say $\blueD{\text{and}}$.  $\greenD{\text{Forty-}}\goldD{\text{two}}$ is to the right of the decimal.  The last place value column is *hundredths*, so we end our number with *hundredths*.  If we combine the parts, we write $\purpleC{9}\blueD{.}\greenD4\goldD2$ as $\purpleC{\text{nine}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{\text{forty-}}\goldD{\text{two hundredths}}$.

This is the completed chart:  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:  $(9\times1)+\left ( 4\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )+\left (2\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )$| $9.42$ | Nine and forty-two hundredths

question.content: **Complete the chart below.**  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:  $4 + 0.4 + 0.002$|  |

options.content: Four and four hundred two thousandths

hints.content: Let's use a place value chart to write $\purpleC{4}+\greenD{0.4}+\goldD{0.002}$ in standard form.  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:|  :-: $\purpleC4$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD4$ | $0$| $\goldD2$

Now, let's break our number into parts to write it in word form: $\purpleC{4}\blueD{.}\greenD40\goldD2$  $\purpleC{\text{Four}}$ is to the left of the decimal.   The decimal tells us to say $\blueD{\text{and}}$.  $\greenD{\text{Four hundred }}\goldD{\text{two}}$ is to the right of the decimal.  The last place value column is *thousandths*, so we end our number with *thousandths*.  If we combine the parts, we write $\purpleC{4}\blueD{.}\greenD40\goldD2$ as $\purpleC{\text{four}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{\text{four hundred }}\goldD{\text{two thousandths}}$.
This is the completed chart:  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:  $4 + 0.4 + 0.002$| $4.402$ | Four and four hundred two thousandths

question.content: **Complete the chart below.**  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:   | $5.28$ |

hints.content: Let's use a place value chart to write $\purpleC5.\greenD2\goldD8$ in expanded form.  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:|  :-: $\purpleC5$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD2$ | $\goldD8$  $\purpleC{(5\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 2\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\goldD{\left (8\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$

Now, let's break our number into parts to write it in word form: $\purpleC5.\greenD2\goldD8$.  $\purpleC{\text{Five}}$ is to the left of the decimal.   The decimal tells us to say $\blueD{\text{and}}$.  $\greenD{\text{Twenty-}}\goldD{\text{eight}}$ is to the right of the decimal.  The last place value column is *hundredths*, so we end our number with *hundredths*.  If we combine the parts, we write $\purpleC{5}\blueD{.}\greenD2\goldD8$ as $\purpleC{\text{five}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{\text{twenty-}}\goldD{\text{eight hundredths}}$.

This is the completed chart:  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:  ${(5\times1)}+{\left ( 2\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+{\left (8\times\dfrac{1}{100} \right )}$| $5.28$ | Five and twenty-eight hundredths

question.content: **Complete the chart below.**  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:   | $6.017$ |

options.content: Six and one hundred seventy thousandths

hints.content: Let's use a place value chart to write $\purpleC6.0\greenD1\goldD7$ in expanded form.  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:|  :-: $\purpleC6$ |$\blueD.$  | $0$| $\greenD1$ | $\goldD7$  $\purpleC{6}+\greenD{0.01}+\goldD{0.007}$

Now, let's break our number into parts to write it in word form: $\purpleC6.0\greenD{17}$.  $\purpleC{\text{Six}}$ is to the left of the decimal.   The decimal tells us to say $\blueD{\text{and}}$.  $\greenD{\text{Seventeen}}$ is to the right of the decimal.  The last place value column is *thousandths*, so we end our number with *thousandths*.  If we combine the parts, we write $\purpleC{6}\blueD{.}0\greenD{17}$ as $\purpleC{\text{six}}$ $\blueD{\text{and}}$ $\greenD{\text{seventeen thousandths}}$.
This is the completed chart:  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:  $6+0.01+0.007$| $6.017$ | Six and seventeen thousandths

question.content: **Complete the chart below.**  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:   |  | Seven and eight hundredths

hints.content: First, let's use a place value chart to write $\purpleC{\text{seven}} \blueD{\text{ and }} \greenD{\text{eight hundredths}}$ in standard form.  The $\blueD{\text{and}}$ tells us where to put the decimal.  We write $\text{\purpleC{seven}}$ to the left side of the decimal as $\purpleC{7}$.  We write $\greenD{\text{eight hundredths}}$ to the right side of the decimal as $\greenD{08}$ .   The last place value in the number is *hundredths*, so the number ends in the *hundredths* place.  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:|  :-: $\purpleC7$ |$\blueD.$  | $0$ | $\greenD8$

Now, let's use the place value chart to put $\purpleC7\blueD.0\greenD8$ in expanded form.  Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:|  :-: $\purpleC7$ |$\blueD.$  | $0$ | $\greenD8$  $\purpleC{7}+\greenD{0.08}$
This is the completed chart:  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:  $7+0.08$| $7.08$ | Seven and eight hundredths

question.content: **Complete the chart below.**  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:   |  | Twenty-one and six hundred five thousandths

hints.content: First, let's use a place value chart to write $\purpleC{\text{twenty-}} \goldD{\text{one}}\blueD{\text{ and }} \greenD{\text{six hundred}}\maroonD{\text{ five thousandths}}$ in standard form.  The $\blueD{\text{and}}$ tells us where to put the decimal.  We write $\purpleC{\text{twenty-}} \goldD{\text{one}}$ to the left side of the decimal as $\purpleC{2}\goldD1$.  We write $\greenD{\text{six hundred}}\maroonD{\text{ five thousandths}}$ to the right side of the decimal as $\greenD{6}0\maroonD5$ .   The last place value in the number is *thousandths*, so the number ends in the *thousandths* place.  Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:|  :-: $\purpleC2$| $\goldD1$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD6$| $0$| $\maroonD5$

Now, let's use the place value chart to put $\purpleC2\goldD1\blueD.\greenD60\maroonD5$ in expanded form.  Tens| Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths| Thousandths :-:|:-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:|  :-: $\purpleC2$| $\goldD1$ |$\blueD.$  | $\greenD6$| $0$| $\maroonD5$  $\purpleC{(2\times10)}+\goldD{(1\times1)}+\greenD{\left ( 6\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+\maroonD{\left (5\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )}$

This is the completed chart:  Expanded Form | Standard Form| Word Form :-:|:-: | :-: | :-:  ${(2\times10)}+(1\times1)+{\left ( 6\times\dfrac{1}{10} \right )}+{\left (5\times\dfrac{1}{1{,}000} \right )}$| $21.605$ | Twenty-one and six hundred-five thousandths
